title: What will be Saudi Arabia's crude oil production for July 2021, according to OPEC?
possible_answers: More than 8,500 tb/d but less than 9,000 tb/d
preds: updating based on the comment provided by @jayb : https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1314686

Reuters survey says Saudi Arabia added 460,000 million bpd to its production in July, slightly above its planned increase of 400,000 bpd. If accurate and if measurement units are the comparable to the GJP question's source, S.A. will likely end July between 9000 and 9500 tb/d. https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/opec-july-oil-output-hits-15-month-high-demand-recovers-survey-shows-2021-07-30/ (Saudi Arabia OPEC oil production figure reported for June '21 was 8,906 tb/d: https://www.opec.org/opec_web/en/publications/338.htm, page 49)

Was increasing during the last months, but it was NEVER above 9.103 during the last 12 months. Do not expect a number above 9.500 at all for July. Under 9.000 is also unlikely because of the trend, but still more likely than above 9.500 since in was under 9.000 in June. @ilguy The agreed increase of production starts in August according to your article. Not relevant for us here. https://tradingeconomics.com/saudi-arabia/crude-oil-production
Gradual increase in production.  But about to be much more significant increase based on limits being raised.  Do not know when the new expanded production will be recorded.

Updating to 100% confidence in 9,000 - 9,500 tb/d because they only needed a 94 tb/d increase to hit that and needed a 694 tb/d to get to 9,500. Oil at $73 per barrel. I think that continued strength in price pushes Saudi Arabia to get above the 9000 tb/d threshold for sure. Will still be shocked if they have a 600+ tb/d increase. Probably around 9,300 - 9,400 tb/d in overall production is my most likely scenario.

Oil at $73 per barrel. I think that continued strength in price pushes Saudi Arabia to get above the 9000 tb/d threshold for sure. Will still be shocked if they have a 600+ tb/d increase. Probably around 9,300 tb/d - 9,400 tb/d in overall production is my most likely scenario.

Given that SA didn't want to increase after August, but they accepted increase of 400K for OPEC for the months after July, I'm thinking it's not so much probable that they commit to +600K increase in July ( for June it was 425K increase). Hence, mostly likely, 9400 tb/d will be the output for July.
Outstanding data and analyses by @alexandemeister at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1309619. Thank you!
OPEC recently agreed to increase production: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/07/18/business/opec-plus-oil-production.html

As @alexandemeister and @slapthepancake highlighted, the report with June data came out yesterday [https://www.opec.org/opec_web/en/].  Per the report, Saudi Arabia oil production was 8.9 mb/d. Demand Considerations:  Currently, the global oil market is in deficit (i.e. demand > supply).  As a result, unless there is a Black-swan event in the Middle East, which curtails supply, it is highly unlikely that oil production for Saudi Arabia will decrease.   Supply Considerations:  It is highly likely that supply will increase, but the better question is, "How much?" +350,000: Saudi Arabia took a voluntary a 1.0 million barrel per day cut earlier this year, and they are starting to release this capacity. Based on looking at the data, this appears to be the primary source of new production releases by OPEC+. There appear to be around 350,000 barrel per day remaining that have not been released fro this voluntary cut.  +133,000: This magnitude seems unlikely as the recent OPEC+ negotiations fell apart at their meeting at the beginning of July.  While there seems to be an accord between KSA and UAE, it still need to be voted upon my OPEC+ and I do not believe there is a meeting scheduled yet. So, here is my current forecast (in thousands): 8,928 + 350*90% + 133*50% = 9,307

Oil demand in the report is growing as of third quarter 2021. I'm thinking there is a high likelihood production is increased by over 94 tb/d and we have not seen a 594 tb/d increase yet so the chance of over 9,500 is low enough to be zero in my eyes. Leaving open the possibility they don't increase because this is always possible, but this is my final thought after skimming the report data and seeing the trend.
Report dropped yesterday showing July production at 8906 bpd, up 425 from June. So anything from 94-594 barrels increase in July would get it to the 9000-9500 bucket

Under quota again for June, they were 41 tb/d below their quota after accounting the self-imposed output cut. They were below by 16 in May as well, and as mentioned have a consistent history of compliance. It is going to be tight, their quota is 9495 and their voluntary cut will end so it'll probably be 9470 or so. Their history is underproduction by a razor thin margin but very consistently, excluding price wars or and stuff like that, so it's hard not to predict underproduction by a razor thin margin again for July.

8,906 in June, still inline with their quotas as described in previous comment. Looks very likely that they'll be near target of 9,495, leaving a a decent chance they overshoot as the question is based on secondary sources, but they haven't overshot in the last couple months. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1285426

Official June OPEC monthly report out on 7/15/21 shows the pertinent (for this question) Saudi Arabia June '21 oil production figure was 8,906 tb/d. (https://www.opec.org/opec_web/en/publications/338.htm, page 49)  The increase from May of 425 tb/d (including revisions) was somewhat higher than I had expected. Older info. had indicated S.A. planned to increase production by 350,000 million b/d in June and 400,000 million b/d in July. (https://www.spglobal.com/platts/en/market-insights/latest-news/oil/061021-saudi-arabia-reports-may-crude-oil-production-of-8544-mil-bd-above-target) July's (upcoming) production increase for S.A. will need to be 595 tb/d or more to exceed the 9,500 forecast option this question.  I currently don't think that amount of production increase is likely but will watch for better/updated information.
Giving more weight to the possibility of Saudi Arabia potentially overproducing for July as they are still 127% compliant w/ their targeted cut
Updated upwards for >9500 due to an argument from Censusguyz : Saudi Arabia could drown Emirates into oil so that they don't do that again
Can't see any reason to adjust current forecasts. Review upon release of next report (15th)

Saudi Arabia has a good history of compliance by secondary figures so despite how close their quota is to the 9500 breakpoint there's still a good chance they'll be below it.  Their spat with the UAE is a bit of a wildcard, but their argument is that output cuts should continue in 2022, so they have good reason not to overproduce while making that argument. They're still working out their differences and oil purchase contracts are arranged in advance, so a price war in the current month like we saw last year with Russia is highly unlikely. Ambiguity is mostly coming from risk of accidental overproduction or noise in the secondary sourcing process as production continues scaling up dramatically after the recent output curbs. I don't give it too much weight though, I tend to overestimate edge cases like that and Saudi Arabia clearly knows how to control production, their compliance history speaks for itself.

June #s are out. SA Production at 8947 tb/day. An increase of 465 vs. May (they had committed to +350). Assuming they continue on the path of adding +400, puts them in 9347 for July. I'm increasing the +9500 probability and virtually eliminating being below 9000 (since they are basically there already with more increases committed for July). The macro situation keeps improving, I'd wager any news here tilts towards an increase in global demand rather than a decrease.
No prior except for existing market

"In a monthly report on Thursday, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries said demand would rise by 6.6% or 5.95 million barrels per day (bpd) this year. The forecast was unchanged for a second consecutive month." ANALYSIS:
There is surging new demand as world recovers from COVI; oil prices are up, bullish market according to last indicators, Saudi Arabia production has been stable between 33%-35% of total production. Assuming a 5% change plus a 95% standard deviation , would mean talking between 8.5-9.5M, with some weight insights.

I updated due to this article : https://www.lemonde.fr/economie/article/2021/07/06/l-absence-d-accord-a-l-opep-risque-d-entrainer-une-flambee-du-petrole_6087195_3234.html ; I didn't know that the plan was to increase of 400 000 by Month and that Emirates were reluctant to do so. Thus the scenario with > 9500 becomes very unlikely and the scenario with <9000 becomes more likely.

According to https://www.bnnbloomberg.ca/opec-oil-output-surged-in-june-to-satisfy-recovering-demand-1.1624483, Saudi Arabia is on an upward trend in terms of production, with 8.95 million a day in June. So less than 9000 tb/d is unlikely. Two scenario left : either there's a huge increase that leads to more than 9500 tb/d, or there's a moderate increase that leads to 9000 to 9500 tb/d.

1. Based on News Reports: "8.95 million a day" (https://www.bnnbloomberg.ca/opec-oil-output-surged-in-june-to-satisfy-recovering-demand-1.1624483)
2. Saudi Arabia took a voluntary a 1.0 million barrel per day cut earlier this year, and they are starting to release this capacity.  Based on looking at the data, this appears to be the primary source of new production releases by OPEC+.  There appear to be around 350,000 barrel per day remaining that have not been released fro this voluntary cut.
3. If OPEC+ increases production by 400,000 per month starting in July, and KSA is ~33% of OPEC+ production, that would mean an increase of 133,000 barrel per day.  
4. Based on news reporting from OPEC+ meetings, KSA seem to indicate they would prefer a gradual and measured increase in supply that aligns with demand.
Going to produce more, prices are going up and they need money

Thank you for the articles @alexandemeister.  Based on comments that "oil market will be in deficit in Short Term, with glut on the horizon", the most likely scenario seems 9-9.5 tb/d with some possibility of higher if the supply cuts diminish DURING July instead of in August.

Per early OPEC+ reports, the supply of oil from those countries is expected to be lower over the coming months than was previously projected.  Will stay alert for the official report but tweaking towards 9-9.5k for now.
Looks like a lot of production increase would be August or later: https://mobile.twitter.com/BloombergAU/status/1410590434083147785?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Etweet

Reuters reporting a 500K bpd increase for June. Combined with the official numbers for May, this puts them just below 9 mln so now am eliminating that bucket. Next month they would need an additional 500+K increase to hit 9500 which is possible but most likely outcomes seems like 9-9500 https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/opec-oil-output-rises-june-demand-recovers-survey-shows-2021-06-30/

No plans to change the output quotas for July, seems like adjustments will come in August. 9500 will be literally 5 tb/d over their quota, and accounting for their voluntary cut they were +13 and -16 in April and May, so they may end up going over more or less accidentally or just as a result of noise in the secondary sourcing process. 
That said, historically the average has been -275 from their quota (minus their excess months), so that may be because their 1M cut was voluntary and less strict, and they have been playing the role of quota enforcer within OPEC, so the gap between quota and production will probably be larger in the future. Still though, they're dramatically scaling up production and planning to increase in August, and an overage of 5 tb/d isn't something other members would harp on them for.

Looking at the updated numbers for the June 2021 report. Saudi oil produced 8,466 barrels with a monthly increase of 345 tb/d. Looking at 2019 production, Saudi oil was producing over 9,600 tb/d with oil prices hovering around the mid $50's. Current prices are around $72 so there is definitely reason to ramp up quickly and produce at high volumes given demand. I'm thinking it might be very difficult to vault up 900 tb/d in a couple months (could be completely wrong here since I don't know the oil industry). I'd give a moderate chance of that, a small chance they really slow their production, and most of my thoughts are that they'll be increasing at a steady rate to leave themselves around 9200-9300 tb/d.
One thing I hadn't considered was SA's desire to produce more with rising oil prices so adjusting for that.

Monthly Oil Market Report - June 2021for OPEC states the production level at 8466tb/d. And as per OPEC+ summit https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/01/business/Opec-plus-oil-prices.html the members are supposed to add 350K in June and 441K in July. Furthermore, SA is supposed to add an extra 350K in June and 400K in July. That would make it total of 1541K addition by end of July. Hence, it's expected to have about 10 million b/d for SA. The fact that oil price has been increasing starting June makes increase in oil production more likely.

June Monthly Oil Market Report (https://www.opec.org/opec_web/en/publications/338.htm) shows slightly over 8,544 tb/d in May, which is a 410 increase on April, which is slightly higher than the projected 350 increase in the FT article, but in the same ballpark. Saudi Arabia is still 1 million barrels below quota in April as expected (based on May OPEC monthly report), and according to their announcements they should be reducing their cut by 250 tb/d in May, 350 tb/d in June, and 400 tb/d in July [1]. OPEC's official production quotas for Saudi Arabia [2] still agree with what link [1] shows after the recent meetings (source of link [2] is here [3]). So if nothing changes we should see the following from Saudi Arabia. If we don't see numbers around these then something is off and I'll have to reduce confidence: April: 8,132 tb/d (actual number from report, quota was 9,119 so this is 987 tb/d below, a bit less than the 1,000 tb/d voluntary cut stated)
May: 8,482 tb/d (quota - 1,000 + 250)
June: 8,947 tb/d (quota - 1,000 + 250 + 350)
July:  9,495 tb/d (quota - 1,000 + 250 + 350 + 400 = full quota) I'm increasing confidence in 9,000 to 9,500 as plans don't appear to have changed. Domonoske, C., (2021 April, 1). OPEC+ To Gradually Boost Oil Production Ahead Of Expected Summer Rebound In Demand. National Public Radio. Retrieved from
https://www.npr.org/2021/04/01/983479830/opec-to-gradually-boost-oil-production-ahead-of-expected-summer-rebound-in-deman Encouraged by vaccination programs and economic stimulus packages, OPEC and its allies are expecting a summertime resurgence in global oil demand and are planning to pump more crude as a result. The announcement on Thursday was a surprise to oil markets, which had anticipated output to hold steady. But it wasn't an unpleasant developent: while supply increases often push prices down, oil actually rose after the news of this apparent optimism. The deal between OPEC members and their allies, collectively called OPEC+, call for production to increase progressively in May, June and July. Meanwhile Saudi Arabia, over the same time frame, will gradually lift its voluntary cuts. Together the two changes will add some 2 million barrels of oil per day to global production by midsummer

Article excerpt: "...The OPEC+ collective oil production is set to rise by 350,000 bpd in both May and June and by more than 400,000 bpd in July. Additionally, Saudi Arabia will also gradually ease its extra unilateral cut of 1 million bpd over the course of the next few months, beginning with monthly production increases of 250,000 bpd in both May and June. Overall, OPEC+ is expected to return to the market as much as 2.1 million bpd by July."  Source: https://oilprice.com/Latest-Energy-News/World-News/Rising-Saudi-Exports-Drive-OPEC-Shipments-Increase-In-May.html For reference the month of April '21 Saudi crude oil production number (via the source for this question) was 8,132 tb/d. (https://www.opec.org/opec_web/en/publications/338.htm, page 50). ..IF S.A. sticks closely to its planned 'gradual' increase in May and June (per above. and the units of measure are the comparable) its crude production would be around 8.6 tb/d at the end of June.

Based on the analysis done by @slapthepancake. I didn't consider the voluntary 1,000tb/d cut that SA implemented.  My previous forecast assumed 600 tb/d increase vs. previous months, reaching 8,800 tb/d. I'm not sure how to consider the 1,000 tb/d recovery. Is that included in OPECs phasing of 2,000 tb/d? Considering SA's quota is just below 9500, it indicates to me that the 1,000 tb/d is included in the total 2,000. Either way, the 600 tb/d increase vs. April seems to be too low of an estimate. If we take at face value the plan of increasing 250, 350 and 400 tb/d for May June and July (respectively), it would mean 9200 tb/d in July. May's production will give us a clear sense of whether these estimates are on track or not. There are some pressure to unwind the 1M cut in oil production. With the current amount still around 8M, I don't see a willingness to go beyond 8.5 by end of July.

Saudi Oil Production
So what seems to be going on is OPEC sets monthly oil production quotas for members, which the members are supposed to not exceed. These were lowered for COVID by 9.7M total May-July, 7.7 August-December, and 7.2 since January. Saudi Arabia also did additional cuts of 1M in February-April to prop up prices and as a goodwill gesture to other OPEC members (according to them), so their quota is lower than normal and their actual production is 1M below their quota. Their current quota is 9.12M, their April production was 8.132. As of the last OPEC meeting, they're planning to phase out their 1M voluntary cut over the next 3 months (https://www.spglobal.com/platts/en/market-insights/latest-news/oil/051021-opec-crude-oil-production-rises-in-april-on-surges-from-iran-russia-platts-survey). Per the current agreement Saudi Arabia's quota will be 9.495 for July 2021 (https://www.opec.org/opec_web/static_files_project/media/downloads/15th%20ONOMM%20-%20Production%20adjustments%20table.pdf).  I assume they'll stick to their stated plan to ease the voluntary cut, so the questions are will OPEC's quotas stay as planned, and will Saudi Arabia comply with them? Compliance is more straightforward, Saudi Arabia has been something of an enforcer for OPEC quotas, and have been very good with quota compliance in the past few years. For 2017 to March 2020 they overproduced in 7 of 39 months, with all the months being at the end of 2018 before their quota was raised the next January after being stagnant for a year and a half. Considering their recent stances on sticking to quotas and taking a voluntary cut themselves, it's not very likely that they'd violate their quota. They probably wouldn't need the excess revenue since the breakeven price for their budget is going down as the economy recovers (https://www.spglobal.com/platts/en/market-insights/latest-news/oil/042221-feature-lower-gulf-fiscal-oil-breakeven-prices-seen-supporting-easing-of-opec-cuts), and it would look a bit hypocritical. That said, more money is always nice and they could say they're entitled to it because of their recent cuts, or they could boost production in response to a faster than expected economic recovery if that recovery isn’t reflected in the quotas. I'd say 85% chance of compliance. When they've been compliant historically they’ve averaged production at 97% of the quota as well, so they should have some wiggle room for small changes in demand should the need arise. More difficult is will OPEC’s quotas be adjusted. What makes it so difficult is that I don’t know what exactly went into the quotas to begin with, so I can’t say if something is or isn’t weighted properly. The quotas are based on projected demand for OPEC crude, and the most recent adjustment was upward by 200k b/d in response to lower projected demand for non-OPEC crude (https://www.argusmedia.com/en/news/2213765-opec-lifts-forecast-call-on-its-crude), so their global oil demand projection from all sources was unchanged as of early May. One of the main points of uncertainty mentioned by Saudi Arabia is the COVID outbreaks in India and Brazil, and India recently agreed to purchase its regular volume in June apparently in response to price cuts from Saudi Arabia (https://www.reuters.com/world/india/exclusive-india-offers-lift-regular-saudi-oil-volumes-june-after-may-cuts-2021-05-07/), as part of a longer saga with deep cuts in May purchases. What that suggests though is that forecasting demand isn’t the same as forecasting economic conditions since demand can be stabilized, partly by price adjustments to account for economic circumstances and partly by the long contract terms (the article also mentions the purchases being agreed upon on an annual basis, making it hard for refiners to shift away from Saudi Arabia as a supplier). On the flip side, greater than expected demand can be met through spot purchases, and annualized contracts don’t prevent additional buying, so a better-than-expected recovery elsewhere may be more impactful. The approach from OPEC led by Saudi Arabia has been “cautiously optimistic” (https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-04-27/opec-prepares-for-meeting-amid-troubling-india-virus-surge) and their recent adjustment was very modest, so I wouldn’t expect a dramatic change in quotas in the coming weeks with that attitude. That said its still possible, their last agreement was before Indian cases started decreasing and upward revisions in response to demand likely wouldn’t be contested much within OPEC.  Something to watch will be May's numbers, especially to clarify whether the +25/35/40 mentioned in the article on their voluntary cut refers to total capacity added back or just the cut independent of quota increases. The June 1 OPEC meeting will be when plans are made for the next two months (June/July), they don't seem to adjust numbers for sooner than that most likely because orders are placed at least that far in advance, so that'll be an important report to check on. Whether the 200k b/d upward revision in OPEC projected demand results in a quota change will also be something to watch.

Correcting my previous forecast because there was an error in my analysis.
In short, OPEC is increasing production by 2,000 tb/d. in April OPEC produced 28.5 million b/d (https://www.eia.gov/opendata/qb.php?category=1039874&sdid=STEO.COPR_OPEC.M), while SA produced 8.15 million b/d (https://www.eia.gov/opendata/qb.php?category=1039874&sdid=STEO.COPR_SA.M). That gives SA about 30% of OPEC's production, so in theory, the increase for SA should be around 600 tb/d, reaching something close to 8800 tb/d.  SA could receive a larger share of the 2,000 tb/d increase, but to reach 9,500 in total production that share would need to be near 75%. I coulnd't find the links now but I had read that SA was withholding production more than other OPEC countries which would justify a larger share of the increase, but I'm unsure whether it would justify such a large share.

Thanks to helpful links shared by @luizbrandao and @SE_Meyer it looks like OPEC's production quota for July is currently 9,495 [1]. This useful chart [2] shows Saudi Arabia's historical production, and shows that they've voluntarily cut by about 1,000. Because it's voluntary I think they're less likely to continue with it by July, and they've indicated they intend to end the cut by July. I'm putting most weight on bucket 4, which is just under their announced quota. As the largest producing member of OPEC I think Saudi Arabia has the most incentive to abide by the quota, which is a maximum allowed if I'm understanding it correctly. But I'm leaving about a 1 in 5 chance in over 9,500 in the event that the quotas get revised up or they overshoot. I'm also leaving a little under 1 in 5 chance that they maintain their voluntary reduction. I think chances are pretty slim that they fall in the 8.5 to 9 category, I would guess by July they'll either stick to their 1 million barrel a day reduction or have eliminated it as opposed to being in the middle of phasing it out. Bear with me, this is my first one. Base Rate
1) Oil production is slightly seasonal, corresponding to a seasonality in crude oil demand from the largest consumers (China, USA) (https://www.danielstrading.com/2020/05/01/summer-seasonality-and-wti-crude-oil-pricing). This means that as a baseline, monthly averages will be slightly more accurate for monthly forecasts than yearly averages.
2) Looking at historic Saudi oil production on aggregate (https://www.eia.gov/opendata/qb.php?category=1039874&sdid=STEO.COPR_SA.M) it has been relatively plateaued since 2016 after a gradual rise since the early 2000's, so restricting my data analysis to only post-2016 data.
3) By breaking down the July oil production from 2016-2019, disregarding July 2020 as they had instituted production cutbacks in the months prior (https://www.cnbc.com/2020/04/12/opec-and-allies-finalize-record-oil-production-cut-after-days-of-discussion.html), we see that the probability of Saudi Arabia producing more than 9.5 mb/d during regular production is 79%, with the mean July production being 10.27 mb/d. HOWEVER
This would assume normal production, and obviously the current cuts are causing the production to fall far below the typical mean. As noted by @luizbrandao:
"   As of Abril 16th:
1. Production has been around 8.1mb/d for Feb and Mar (https://www.eia.gov/opendata/qb.php?category=1039874&sdid=STEO.COPR_SA.M)
2. WTI and Brent Oil prices are between $63 and $66 (https://oilprice.com/oil-price-charts/)
3. Futures are holding steady at $60 (https://www.marketwatch.com/investing/future/crude%20oil%20-%20electronic)
4. While vaccinations are speeding up across the world, most of the world's population won't be inoculated for a while. We're at 200mi with 2 doses and 300mi with 1 dose (half a billion at least partially inoculated), and delivering around 13mi/day (https://github.com/owid/covid-19-data/blob/master/public/data/vaccinations/vaccinations.csv). New variants are still at risk and there is talk of a potential third dose (https://www.reuters.com/business/healthcare-pharmaceuticals/us-preparing-1-year-covid-19-booster-shots-pfizer-chief-sees-need-2021-04-15/). At current rates we will be vaccinating well into 2023; at double capacity, we'd still be vaccinating well into 2022. TL;DR Demand for crude will be slow to pick up, and that's assuming no new negative developments   " So, if the current cuts continue, even with moderate increases, we would still see production fall into the 8-8.5 mb/d range, with it being very unlikely (on the order of 1-3%) that production falls below that range.  According to Financial Post (https://financialpost.com/commodities/game-of-chicken-the-saudis-and-russians-can-wage-an-oil-war-for-a-long-time-but-at-a-huge-political-cost?video_autoplay=true), Saudi Arabia has more than enough wiggle room to keep the cuts going for as long as they feel that COVID is suppressing demand. While Wall Street Journal (COVID-19 slashed Carbon Emissions. Now They're Climbing Again.) reports that emissions and carbon consumption are back on the rise, and the oil prices (noted above) are rising as well, the worldwide case against COVID is worsening, meaning we could just as easily see things turn back around. SO, my prediction is that it is the most likely scenario that the cuts are still in place through July, 2021, making it the most likely scenario that production is in the 8-8.5 mb/d bucket. However, the next most likely scenario is that the game of chicken between Russia and Saudi comes to a halt and both countries ease restricitons, which would cause Saudi production to shoot up closer to the historic mean, meaning the next most likely scenario is that July production falls in the >9.5 mb/d bucket. .

They may decide with Biden's halt to the Pipelines bringing oil sands oil south to continue to up the economic pressure on these oil sources to drive them out of business. Unlikely as they are noticing an increase in salinity in gulf oils indicating infusion into the reservoirs of seawater and they don't want to kill the golden goose too quickly.

To forecast oil production and supply in July 2021, what are the factors that determine?
1. Oil prices - In March 2021, average Brent Price was USD 65.41. It is almost the price level in 2019. During Pandemic, it dropped to a low of USD 32.
2. Oil Demand - Demand is expected to be 95 million barrels per day. Better vaccination, return to pre-pandemic consumption pattern will determine this. Due to pandemic, investment in capacities has slowed down. Hence, Saudi Arabia is in a better position to increase its market share to > 15%, provided 1 and 2 are favorable. Hence, we need to watch for price trends and demand patterns. If it remains the same, then production will be 8 - 8.5 million bpd. If there is a situation to normalcy, then there are chances for increase in production by 10% https://knoema.com/yxptpab/crude-oil-price-forecast-2021-2022-and-long-term-to-2050

Actually, the framework for quotas of OPEC+ allows for Saudi Arabia's production (unwinding voluntary cuts included) to increase to exactly 9,495tb/d, which is the same production quota as for non-OPEC Russian Federation. Thus, the exact outcome will depend on a couple of factors:
/the recovery of global economic activity, particularly in oil-importing nations, and thus overall demand
/global travel
/U.S. national crude oil stocks
/OPEC+ quota discipline, and quota amendments before June 2021 due to changes in demand outlook (external shocks, the global COVID-19 pandemic situation)
/revival of the Russia - Saudi Arabia "oil market war", which is a battle for market share in the first place, and would see Saudi Arabia increasing output volume and thus lowering average prices realized for the cartel as a whole. As the government of KSA plans to enable their budget to become more independent of Saudi Aramco's dividend payments in the future and to increase the assets under management held by their sovereign wealth funds significantly by 2025 by budget cuts in the near term, it seems these are precautions taken for more resilience against the impact of financial fallout in a next round of the race for market dominance against Russia.
/Industrialized importing nations, who tended to deplete their strategic stockpiles over the past 14 months of ready supply at low prices, could be forced to refill stores amid strong global economic growth perspectives and sticky oil prices around 60USD/bbl. Hedging demand by air carriers could pick up due to increased demand for transportation of cargo and passengers. Both would likely drive OPEC+ output volumes as well as prices at least temporarily.
/This would mean the question resolves on the 5th bin, if KSA's production only marginally exceeds their currently planned quota by more than 5tb/d, or 0.063%,  in July 2021, which is peak tavel season (peak fuel demand in the Northern hemisphere). Next MOMR published 13 April 2021.
